title: As a Westerner creating a name for a Japanese man for a story, what are some of the basic rules and things that I should avoid? - Quora

response.answer_text: Basic rule 1. Study up on male names in Japanese history, specifically family names. There are some which are obscure, and some which are very common. Searching for Common Japanese Surnames: Not knowing the scope of your story, and implications for comedy, drama, horror, suspense or other genres, these are some good web sites to peruse in order to come up with something perhaps pertinent to your story. Japanese names, as I’m sure you realize, involve Chinese characters which have an underlying meaning for the name itself, and can potentially have a related context to your story, or somewhat fanciful. https://japantoday.com/category/features/lifestyle/the-10-most-common-surnames-in-japan-and-their-meanings Japan's top 100 most common family names | The Japan Times The following link gives some relationships to names and what they might indicate for a families historical connection to a trade, to a samurai family or anything in between. Japanese Last Names This next one is particularly nice because it gives a long list of family names and the meanings assigned to them. Japanese Surnames As for personal names, if you have your story set 20 to 30 years in the past, given names were more rigidly followed. From the last 20 to the present, there has been a trend to adopt names in katakana, indicating that they are not common names in Japanese since katakana is used primarily for foreign words and names, and in a few instances I’ve seen foreign names adopted by a native Japanese family for an offspring, even writing it in Romaji, the western alphabet. You have a lot from which to choose.MJP

Names don’t age well in Japan. Or perhaps I should say that personal names show their age. How old is the man in your story? I assume he is from Japan. Not a Japanese person born overseas?? Different types of names were popular let’s say 80 years ago. But no one would use those names now. You could pick a name that’s suitable for 80-year-old man but if you gave that to someone who is 25 in your story, it would be ridiculous. It would be like giving a 25 year old the name “Wilber”. Here is a list of the top 200 most popular family names. Any one of these would be suitable as a “last” name - - you understand that Japanese family names come first, right?? 日本人の名字ランキング Here is a list of the most popular personal names decade by decade for the last 100 years. So depending on how old your man is, you can pick the correct decade: 名前の流行100年史　戦前は「清」、戦後は…｜エンタメ！｜NIKKEI STYLE Unfortunately you’re going to have to ask the help of a Japanese person to get the reading for these names as only the Chinese character is supplied in these lists. And you can not click on the character to copy it. But these lists are a great resource. If you decide on a selection and can’t get any help with the reading contact me again and I will try to figure out what it is. And as a last resort, I could type the character and get someone in Japan to read it for me. Good luck!

some womens names end in-mi, -ko and -ka, so avoid calling boys with these names, also names that mention nature or seasons such as Natsu, Fuyu, some boys are called Haru or Aki. Stay away frm names like Ai (love) Some family names have one Kanji, most have two and the very rare one has three, Make sure you use them properly or it just looks weird. It would be like calling your kid Justice, Sunshine or Symphony in English

I would consult with a native-speaker of Japanese. For some reasons, mis-pronounced words sometimes sound like sex or hygiene related. I do not know why this is. A revered case is a Japanese tooth past that has a product name, which sounds like “a con-artist’s tooth paste.” Oh, this is a case of a product with a demeaning name.

Two common mistakes.(1) Not knowing which names are family names and which are given names. (2) Not knowing which are male names and which are female names. Some can be either, but the kanji may be different.
Avoid first names ending in -ko which is the suffix for child. It's normally tied to female names.
